snippet: Business groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special House primary runoff that is seen as a test case for the fight over the Republican Party’s future.
abstract: Business groups like the US Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special Republican primary runoff for Congress in South Alabama, backing pro-business candidate Bradley Byrne; effort is seen as fight for Republican Party's future, as many business leaders become increasingly concerned that anti-establishment Tea Party conservatives will derail the party's larger agenda.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and ERIC LIPTON
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson reported from Mobile, and Eric Lipton from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Business groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special House primary runoff that is seen as a test case for the fight over the Republican Party’s future.

headline.main: In Alabama Race, a Test of Business Efforts to Derail Tea Party
headline.print_headline: In Alabama Race, a Test of Business Efforts to Derail Tea Party
